en2: Advanced users can change these input values to see how different assumptions about the population affect the model's results.

en: Projected adult female population size over time. The darker line shows the outcome if we ignore uncertainty about demographic rates and variation among years. The paler lines show a variety of plausible outcomes given uncertainty about demographic rates and variation among years. Only the female population is shown because it is assumed that the number of females is what limits population growth. The population is considered stable if the line is flat or sloped upwards and is declining if the line slopes downward.
en2: Projected adult female population size over time. The thicker line shows the outcome without considering any uncertainty. The paler lines show a variety of outcomes that include uncertainty about female survival rates, number of calves per 100 cows, and yearly variation.   Only the female population is shown since the number of females is what limits population growth. The population is considered stable if the line is flat or sloped up and is shrinking if the line slopes down.

en: The mean % female mortality and female replacement rate in each scenario. The error bars show the minimum and maximum expected values given the uncertainty in the population parameters. A population is stable or increasing when the female replacement rate is equal to or greater than % female mortality.
en2: The average % female mortality and female replacement rate in each scenario. The error bars show the minimum and maximum considering uncertainty in the data. A population is stable or increasing when the female replacement rate is equal to or greater than % female mortality.

en: Note that the data summarized and described here is provided by app users, and will differ among projects. The creators of the app do not take responsibility for the quality of the data. Click the “update data” button on the menu to the left and follow instructions to modify the data or data description.
en2: Note that the data summarized and described here is provided by app users, and will differ among projects. The creators of the app do not take responsibility for the quality of the data. Click the “update data” button on the menu to the left and follow instructions to modify the data or data description.

en: Note that results will not be shown for populations with only one year of recruitment or survival data because one year of data is insufficient for making reliable predictions.
en2: If a popoulation has only one year of data for either survival of females or calf and female counts, no results will be shown. One year is not enough information to make a reliable prediction.

en: Provide a URL linking to a Google Drive spreadsheet
en2: Provide a URL linking to a Google Drive spreadsheet

en: Instructions to create a new data sheet
en2: Instructions to create a new data sheet

en: You can supply a URL for your own Google Sheet to use your own data in the app.
en2: You can supply a URL for your own Google Sheet to use your own data in the app.

en: In your Google Drive account click 'New' and select 'Google Sheets'
en2: In your Google Drive account click 'New' and select 'Google Sheets'

en: Fill the spreadsheet with your data. It must have the same sheets, and column names as the
en2: Fill the spreadsheet with your data. It must have the same sheets, and column names as the

en: for more information on how to format the data.
en2: for more information on how to format the data.

en: Note: The data must be in a Google Sheet not an Excel file stored on Google Drive. To use an uploaded Excel file click 'File', then 'Save as Google Sheets'.
en2: Note: The data must be in a Google Sheet not an Excel file stored on Google Drive. To use an uploaded Excel file click 'File', then 'Save as Google Sheets'.

en: If access to the Google Sheet is restricted it will be necessary to grant access to the app.
en2: If access to the Google Sheet is restricted it will be necessary to grant access to the app.

en: The simpler option is to click 'Share' and under General Access select 'Anyone with the link` and choose the role 'Viewer'.
en2: The simpler option is to click 'Share' and under General Access select 'Anyone with the link` and choose the role 'Viewer'.

en: Then click 'Copy link'. Paste the link into the text box above and click `Update`
en2: Then click 'Copy link'. Paste the link into the text box above and click `Update`

en: The url provided is for a protected Google sheet.
en2: The url provided is for a protected Google sheet.

en: Click the Authenticate button below and follow the instructions to give this app permission to access files in your Google drive.
en2: Click the Authenticate button below and follow the instructions to give this app permission to access files in your Google drive.

en: Alternatively, change the settings on the Google sheet so "Anyone with the link can view"
en2: Alternatively, change the settings on the Google sheet so "Anyone with the link can view"

en: Note, this graph displays the number of animals counted in aerial surveys in each year. The survey area or time spent surveying may differ from year to year so the numbers should not be directly compared from one year to the next. These values are used by the model to estimate the ratios of males to females and females to calves in the population.
en2: Note, this graph displays the number of animals counted in aerial surveys in each year. The survey area or time spent surveying may differ from year to year so the numbers should not be directly compared from one year to the next. These values are used by the model to estimate the ratios of males to females and females to calves in the population.
